input.instruction: Integrate these notes into economy/politics structures; propose links and detect conflicts.

summary: Proposed initial structure docs for Politics & Economy, linked monetary system to governance, and flagged a contradiction around 'moneyless communism' vs 'currency-based purchases'.

adds.title: Political System
adds.content:
## Overview
- The world is described as 'communist' in note n_001.
- Governance: central planning committee.

## Open Questions
- How is scarcity handled?

adds.title: Economic System
adds.content:
## Currency
- Note n_002 suggests a currency with special properties (transfer limits, decay).

## Markets
- Purchases exist for luxury items.

excerpts: "There is a currency... you need to purchase"

links.note: Currency-based purchases may contradict a strict moneyless communist model; needs reconciliation.

items.excerpt: There is a currency... need to purchase

conflicts.explanation: Two notes imply incompatible economic mechanisms unless the 'currency' is reinterpreted (e.g., token for rationing) or communism is partial/ideological only.

resolutionOptions.title: Reinterpret 'currency' as ration tokens
resolutionOptions.proposal: Keep communist framing; redefine currency as non-tradeable allocation tokens tied to production quotas.
cons: Requires rules to prevent black markets

resolutionOptions.title: Make communism ideological, not literal moneyless
resolutionOptions.proposal: State ideology is communist, but a controlled currency exists for certain sectors.
cons: Needs political justification and enforcement mechanisms
